Application_Facts: Judge reviewed landlord letters, tax assessments, and travel records; gaps in income documentation and lost passport noted
Residency_Compliance: Assessed through credible evidence despite gaps
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Missing income documentation
Lost passport
Credibility_Assessment: Evidence found credible by citizenship judge
Relief_Sought: Challenged citizenship approval due to insufficient evidence
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied in judicial review
Decision_Rationale: Decision was justified, transparent, and intelligible; fell within acceptable range of outcomes

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Mr. El Bousserghini and Ms. Kranfouli were physically present in Canada for over 1,095 days during the four-year period preceding their citizenship application
Procedural_Issue: Minister challenged the decision on grounds of insufficient evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged by Minister, but not proven
Credibility_Assessment: Passive indicia accepted as sufficient by Citizenship Judge
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Decision_Rationale: No palpable error demonstrated by Minister; evidence sufficient to support residency claim

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1099 days of physical presence in Canada over four years but had undeclared absences and inconsistent documentation
Residency_Compliance: Alleged non-compliance with 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to provide adequate reasoning on how absences affected day count or why evidence was insufficient
Evidence_Used: Documentation provided by Ms. Hussein showing 1099 days of presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent records and lack of explanation for absences
Credibility_Assessment: Judge questioned sufficiency of evidence but did not clearly assess credibility or explain reasoning
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application rejected based on residency grounds
Relief_Sought: Overturn of rejection and re-determination of application
Remedy_Sought: Remand for redetermination by a new decision-maker
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient justification provided by Citizenship Judge for rejecting the evidence and residency calculation

Legal_Provision_Violated: Physical presence test under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Respondent applied for Canadian citizenship, claiming sufficient residency days despite inconsistencies in travel documentation and financial records
Residency_Compliance: Alleged compliance not supported by evidence; discrepancies in passport stamps, ICES reports, and bank statements
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation regarding actual physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasoning by Citizenship Judge failing to address contradictory evidence
Evidence_Used: Passport entry/exit stamps, ICES reports, bank statements
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to reconcile conflicting evidence on residency duration
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient credibility analysis conducted by the Citizenship Judge
Decision_Outcome: Original approval of citizenship application set aside
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter remitted for redetermination
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different Citizenship Judge
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of engagement with key contradictory evidence and inadequate reasons
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirement for citizenship
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge unreasonably approved the application despite insufficient and inconsistent evidence of residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's testimony lacked credibility due to memory lapses and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient and inconsistent evidence of residency compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence and proper assessment by the judge
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence for absences from Canada
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicants must prove residency with credible evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship approval set aside; respondent may reapply
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court under Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirement for citizenship
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge reasonably assessed the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act subsection 14(5), Federal Courts Act section 21
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's explanation for absences lacked credibility due to memory lapses and lack of documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act subsection 14(5), Federal Courts Act section 21
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inaccurate reporting of absences from Canada during the residency period
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence and failure to justify decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation of physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Quantitative or qualitative test for residency, with justification required
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Significant discrepancies in the respondent’s reported absences
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicants must prove residency through credible evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Citizenship revoked; respondent may reapply in accordance with the law
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court under Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in finding residency compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's credibility questioned due to inconsistent statements
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation in application affecting residency claim
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistent reporting of absences and potential misrepresentation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act and s. 21 of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose all absences from Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Discrepancies in absence reporting and passport evidence not adequately addressed
Crimes.Application_Factor: Accuracy and completeness of residency information

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the 1095-day physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting evidence on absences and passport indicating unreported travel
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove physical presence for 1095 days
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent reporting affecting reliability of claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Citizenship Act and Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Whether the appellant meets the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant accumulated 357 days of residence; no exceptions applied
Burden_of_Proof: On the appellant to demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Legal_Rule: Applicant must have at least three years (1,095 days) of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment by citizenship judge
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency due to studying abroad
Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of days physically present in Canada: 357

Application_Facts: Applicant failed to disclose multiple trips outside Canada during the required residency period
Residency_Compliance: Did not demonstrate physical presence in Canada for at least 1,095 days
Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose absences undermining credibility
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of denial of procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient credible evidence of physical presence
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility was found to be lacking due to omissions in travel disclosure
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge's conclusion was reasonable; no breach of procedural fairness occurred

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed his visitor visa and failed to attend initial proceedings; later attended with counsel.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of notice and denial of interpreter rights
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to issue exclusion order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Proof of visa overstay, attendance records, representation by counsel, language comprehension
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found – applicant understood English and was represented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of lack of notice not supported by evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of removal order and procedural reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; mandatory exclusion order under Regulation 228 due to overstay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, missed initial proceedings, later attended with counsel; claimed lack of notice, interpreter issues, and ignored H&C factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Claims of inadequate notice, lack of interpreter, and failure to consider H&C
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of immigration officer’s duty in procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of non-attendance, counsel representation, demonstrated English comprehension, absence of H&C referral requirement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C claims not substantiated or required at exclusion stage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood proceedings; interpreter not necessary
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn exclusion order based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion for inadmissibility under subsection 29(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to provide interpreter when comprehension evident; H&C considerations separate from exclusion orders

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under section 28
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visitor visa and did not fulfill residency obligations; submitted H&C application but excluded from IAD referral
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to issue exclusion without IAD referral when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa duration records, departure history, submission of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C factors not grounds to bypass mandatory exclusion under section 28
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No challenge to credibility; focus on legal applicability
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order issued lawfully without IAD referral
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and refer to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Procedural referral to Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion under IRPA when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 28 requires exclusion order without IAD referral if inadmissibility is based solely on overstay

Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa in Canada
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied incorrect standard of review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether RAD has authority to apply reasonableness standard
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by RPD and upheld by RAD
Outcome: RAD decision set aside, case remanded
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by RAD using correct standard
Decision_Rationale: RAD is an appellate body and must apply palpable and overriding error or hybrid standard

Victim_Status: Individual at risk due to family wealth and perceived activism
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant credible but denied claim on other grounds

Key_Evidence_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Dispute_Type: Standard of review in refugee appeals
Consequences_of_Action: RAD decision set aside, remanded for redetermination

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on extortion risk
Legal_Issue: Appropriate standard of review for RAD
Evidence_Assessment: Fear based on family wealth and conflict environment
Decision_Outcome: Claim denied by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate well-founded fear
Legal_Rule: RAD must apply palpable and overriding error standard
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of extortion and forced enlistment in Syria
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached due to procedural error

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving nondisclosure of activities
Legal_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove eligibility for protection
Legal_Rule: RAD must substitute its decision unless bound by credibility findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived activism and fundraising
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided due to procedural error
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside

Crimes.Crime_Name: Knowingly Concealing Material Circumstances in Immigration Process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Odynsky served as an auxiliary guard at Nazi labor camps during WWII and did not disclose this when applying for Canadian citizenship.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Complied with residency requirements but obtained status through concealment
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose wartime activities that were material to admissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Proceedings initiated by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian citizenship law
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct documentation of disclosure during initial immigration screening
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found Odynsky's explanation less credible than evidence indicating concealment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deprivation of citizenship under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Admission to Canada was based on failure to disclose material wartime involvement that would have led to rejection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation based on false representation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Odynsky obtained citizenship through false representation or concealment of material facts
Crimes.Outcome: Citizenship declared obtained by false representation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found it more probable than not that Odynsky misrepresented or concealed his wartime role
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Involuntary service with German auxiliary forces and failure to disclose during immigration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Likelihood that disclosure would have resulted in denial of entry
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative hearing under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose material wartime activities on immigration and citizenship applications
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; court relied on available historical and testimonial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: False representation or knowingly concealing material circumstances under s. 10 and s. 18
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and extent of collaboration with Nazi forces
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Declaration that citizenship was obtained by false representation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct document forgery, but omission constituted fraudulent misrepresentation

Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient - CSC relied on reliable sources
Credibility_Assessment: Reliable information used
Sentencing_Issue: Life imprisonment with no parole for 25 years

Judicial review procedures

Evidentiary_Deficiency: No significant inaccuracies found
Credibility_Assessment: CSC sources deemed reliable
Decision_Rationale: Proper procedures followed
Reliable sources used

Application_Facts: Assessment refusal cited as factor in classification

Procedural_Issue: Due process in classification
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No procedural error found

Decision_Rationale: Refusal considered within risk assessment framework

Credibility_Factor: CSC's use of documented, reliable data
Legal_Rule: Classification must be based on accurate, complete information

Dispute_Type: Security classification based on inmate compatibility
Legal_Issue: Impact of incompatibility claims on classification
Evidence_Assessment: Minimal impact of escape risk on decision

Procedural_Issue: Use of judicial review to challenge administrative decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inaccuracies did not affect outcome
Credibility_Assessment: Overall decision found credible
Decision_Rationale: Severity of crime outweighed minor discrepancies

Application_Facts: Challenge to adequacy of grievance resolution
Procedural_Issue: Grievance process adherence
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of CSC decisions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No material error identified
Credibility_Assessment: CSC process found credible
Decision_Rationale: Process followed regulations
Decision justified

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility of non-accompanying family member under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's son has moderate mental retardation and was non-accompanying; concerns about future sponsorship and excessive demand on services
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Principal applicant seeking immigration to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Son intended to remain in China initially
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical diagnosis of son, applicant’s statements regarding non-accompaniment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible mitigation plan for potential future excessive demand
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's mitigation plans deemed not credible by visa officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Potential future excessive demand not mitigated despite non-accompaniment; future sponsorship rights preserved

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to health condition
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether non-accompanying family member's health condition leads to inadmissibility
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act s. 38(1)(c) and s. 42
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Medical evidence of son’s moderate mental retardation considered
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate no excessive demand
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to provide sufficient individualized plan
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Excessive demand on health or social services triggers inadmissibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Diagnosis of moderate mental retardation, lack of mitigation plan
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant argued son would not accompany and costs would not be incurred
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside refusal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Excessive demand on health or social services
Crimes.Violation_Type: Excessive demand due to health condition
Crimes.Application_Facts: Son diagnosed with moderate mental retardation; potential future demand if sponsored
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Principal applicant applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Medical reports, applicant's intent to sponsor in future
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credible plan to mitigate potential service costs
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assertion that son would remain abroad not sufficient to negate future risk
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn refusal based on health inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Assessment of excessive demand under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Potential future demand remains even if not accompanying now; sponsorship rights preserved

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide credible individualized plan to mitigate excessive demand
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Right to family unity vs. public resource protection
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unfairness in requiring detailed mitigation plans for non-accompanying dependents
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law and humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Visa refusal based on incomplete mitigation strategy
Crimes.Protected_Group: Persons with disabilities (son with moderate mental retardation)
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Canada may be required to provide support if individual is sponsored
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Future burden on social services upon sponsorship
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant's plan not deemed credible or specific enough
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: System allows exemptions but requires proof of mitigation
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Family separation due to inadmissibility of disabled dependent

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Enforcement of court order
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Respondent be held in contempt for failing to pay a fine and costs?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 466(1)(b) and Rule 471 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence confirmed service of the April 7, 2006 Order and non-compliance by the Respondent
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Met by the Applicant through testimony on service and non-payment
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondent did not appear or provide valid justification
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Non-compliance with court orders may result in contempt, fines, costs, and imprisonment
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of compliance with court order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to pay $2,000 fine and $1,000 costs as ordered
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Warrant of Committal and additional costs
Crimes.Outcome: Warrant of Committal issued; additional costs of $1,000 assessed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a court order
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with financial obligations under court order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: April 7, 2006 Court Order requiring payment of fine and costs
Crimes.Governing_Law: Rule 466(1)(b) and Rule 471 of the Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent failed to pay $2,000 fine and $1,000 costs despite service and reminders
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ex parte motion filed due to Respondent's non-appearance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent offered irrelevant documents instead of compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Warrant of Committal issued; additional $1,000 costs imposed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Imprisonment via Warrant of Committal and recovery of additional costs
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Contempt for failure to comply with court order
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective review of compliance with court directive
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Willful non-compliance with clear court order after proper notice

Governing_Law: Canadian law on Convention refugees and persons in need of protection
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Costa Rica after alleged rape and threats; claimed fear of persecution and inability to access state protection
Claimant_Status: Applicants seeking refugee status in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following RPD decision; applicants argued inadequate state protection but did not pursue all available avenues in Costa Rica
Evidence_Used: RPD considered mechanisms such as the Ombudsman and special courts in Costa Rica
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicants failed to provide sufficient evidence that state protection was unavailable; claims of ineffective police not substantiated by exhausting remedies
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicants must demonstrate inability to access state protection; perfection in state protection not required
Decision_Rationale: Costa Rica provides adequate state protection through existing legal mechanisms; applicants did not prove that protection was unavailable despite available avenues

Application_Facts: Alcon sought to prevent Cobalt from selling a generic olopatadine product by claiming the 924 Patent was valid.
Procedural_Issue: A Notice of Objection (NOA) was filed by Cobalt challenging the validity of Alcon's 924 Patent.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to demonstrate or predict utility across all claimed molecular weights of PVP
Decision_Outcome: The court dismissed Alcon's application, declaring the 924 Patent invalid for lack of utility and overbreadth.
Outcome: The 924 Patent is invalid due to lack of demonstrated or soundly predicted utility and overbreadth.
Decision_Rationale: The court found insufficient evidence to support the utility of the patent across the full scope of claims, and determined that the claims were broader than what was demonstrated or predicted.

Application_Facts: Applicants sought visas to attend a wedding in Canada; had employment, property, and children in Nigeria; limited travel history; sufficient financial considerations
Residency_Compliance: Applicants demonstrated strong ties to country of residence (Nigeria)
Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness; no interview offered despite concerns; failure to consider key evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer disregarded strong evidence of ties to Nigeria
Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted return intention without adequate justification
Decision_Outcome: Visa denied based on presumed non-compliance with IRPA §20(1)(b)
Outcome: Decision found patently unreasonable; overturned on judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of visa application by a different officer
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to properly assess applicant's ties to home country and did not provide opportunity to respond to concerns

Application_Facts: Applicant had discrepancies in residency evidence, including conflicting addresses and unclear living arrangements
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day residency requirement over four years
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent or insufficient evidence of residency, but no explicit finding of intentional misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Residency records, addresses, living arrangement details
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Conflicting addresses, lack of clear documentation supporting physical presence
Credibility_Assessment: Residency evidence found not credible or insufficient by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; original decision upheld
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative test (Re Pourghasemi) and qualitative test (Koo) for residency under Section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that applicant failed to provide sufficient credible evidence to establish required residency under any applicable test

Application_Facts: Mrs. Khan's citizenship claim relied on Article 45 of Guyana's Constitution, which grants discretion to authorities; the tribunal speculated on how Guyana might exercise its discretion. Mr. Khan faced credible events in Guyana but did not claim refugee status in the U.S.
Claimant_Status: Mrs. Khan used a false passport raising questions about her citizenship rights; Mr. Khan faced criminal acts in Guyana.
Misrepresentation_Element: Use of a false passport by Mrs. Khan
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to conduct a proper section 97 analysis for Mr. Khan
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Speculation by tribunal on discretionary powers under Article 45 without concrete evidence of citizenship grant
Credibility_Assessment: Questions raised about Mrs. Khan’s citizenship due to use of false passport
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remitted for reconsideration
Relief_Sought: Recognition of right to protection under section 97
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution; requirements under sections 96 and 97 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred in assuming Mrs. Khan’s citizenship rights based on speculative application of discretionary constitutional provision; failed to analyze Mr. Khan’s section 97 claim despite credible harm

Dispute_Type: Citizenship rights and eligibility for protection under Canadian immigration law
Legal_Issue: Whether Mrs. Khan had a right to Guyanese citizenship and whether Mr. Khan qualified for protection under section 97
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, tribunal decision quashed, case remitted
Credibility_Assessment: Mrs. Khan used false identity information on marriage certificate affecting credibility of claims
Evidence_Type: Marriage certificate with false identity information
Legal_Provision: Section 97 of IRPA; Article 45 of Guyana's Constitution
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged errors in legal interpretation and evidence assessment by tribunal
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of false identity in official document (marriage certificate) leading to misrepresentation
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review before the Federal Court
Application_Error: Assumption of Mrs. Khan’s citizenship rights despite discretionary nature of Guyanese citizenship process
Assessment_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; proper analysis under section 97 required
Evidence_Ignored: Failure to properly assess events in Guyana relevant to Mr. Khan’s risk under section 97
Legal_Standard: Standard for establishing well-founded fear and eligibility for state protection under IRPA
Application_Factor: Prior use of fraudulent documents and failure to seek protection in U.S.
Document_Fraud: False identity information on marriage certificate

Crime_Name: Negligence in Search and Rescue Duties
Application_Facts: The ship was sold before the action commenced, disallowing in rem claims. However, the in personam claim remains valid as it falls under federal navigation and shipping jurisdiction.
Procedural_Issue: Defendants moved to strike or stay the action based on jurisdictional grounds
Jurisdictional_Issue: Can the Federal Court hear an action against federal and provincial defendants for damages arising from a boating accident under maritime law?
Decision_Outcome: The motion to strike the in personam action is dismissed; the in rem action is dismissed due to lack of continuous ownership.
Outcome: In personam action continues in Federal Court; in rem action dismissed. Defendants must file statements of defense by January 11, 2012.
Decision_Rationale: The in personam claim falls within federal navigation and shipping jurisdiction, allowing it to proceed. The in rem claim fails because the vessel was sold before the action began, breaking continuous ownership required for such claims.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section C.08.002 of the Food and Drug Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicant filed a New Drug Submission (NDS) relying on literature references instead of required clinical trial data.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application challenging administrative decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clinical trial data in NDS submission
Decision_Outcome: Health Canada's rejection of NDS upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Health Canada's decision
Decision_Rationale: Section C.08.002 requires clinical trial data; applicant failed to provide it; reliance on literature insufficient; Health Canada acted within regulatory authority.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Senior Official in Regime with Human Rights Violations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Male applicant served as Lieutenant Colonel (rank 6 of 17) in the Iraqi army under Saddam Hussein's regime; Officer used military hierarchy charts and consulted War Crimes Unit to assess seniority.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of duty of fairness during assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants were given opportunity to respond; no deficiency noted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Position fell within top half of military hierarchy; decision was reasonable and transparent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Violation of human or international rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility based on association with regime committing human rights violations
Crimes.Outcome: No violation found by reviewing body; application dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Male applicant’s role as senior military official in Saddam Hussein’s regime
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, international human rights standards
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Assessment by Immigration Officer with input from War Crimes Unit
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Regime engaged in human rights violations
Crimes.Credibility: Applicants had opportunity to respond; credibility not directly challenged
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed inadequate due to nature of regime

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 87(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) - Procedural Fairness
Application_Facts: Applicant's permanent residence application was refused based on alleged fraudulent employment certificates and credibility concerns; officer relied on unclear CAIPS notes and contacted wrong Johnson Controls office; Tower letter misinterpreted despite evidence of full-time employment
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fraudulent employment certificates, but no proven intentional misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide applicant with opportunity to respond to credibility concerns
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Unclear CAIPS notes
Clerical error in verification (wrong office contacted)
Misinterpretation of supporting documents
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on flawed verification and lack of applicant response opportunity
Decision_Outcome: Visa refusal upheld initially by officer
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by different officer after procedural fairness is observed
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer violated procedural fairness by not informing applicant of credibility concerns and denying right to respond before making adverse decision
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada using a false Japanese passport and lacked original identity documents.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to use of false documents
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to thoroughly analyze additional documents with security features
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of submitted documents by the Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations dismissed without thorough review
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied due to insufficient identity proof
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remission for re-determination by a new Board
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimants must establish identity through acceptable documentation or provide reasonable explanations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Unreasonable dismissal of evidence regarding identity

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Identity verification in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board's assessment of applicant's identity
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Summary dismissal of household register, school certificates, and official stamps without thorough authenticity examination
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish identity, but Board must consider all evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Documents provided contained official markings but were not properly evaluated
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Board must consider all evidence and explanations regarding identity
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to adequately analyze identity documents
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board dismissed documents due to lack of security features
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Re-evaluation by a newly constituted Board

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96-97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection in Canada as a Christian fearing persecution in China; Member rejected claim due to perceived implausibilities and lack of religious knowledge
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide concrete reasons for credibility findings
Inadequate consideration of cultural context and regional legal variances
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to support implausibility findings
Misinterpretation of religious practices and Chinese law enforcement practices
Credibility_Assessment: Findings based on unsupported assumptions
Ignored regional variances in law enforcement and religious practice
Decision_Rationale: Errors in law and fact-finding, including failure to properly assess credibility and country conditions

Dispute_Type: Complaint of racial discrimination in a federal workplace
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission reasonably applied s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant was given 90 days by the Chief of Defence Staff to file a harassment complaint but did not do so
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate that internal procedures were not reasonably available or that failure to use them was justified
Credibility_Factor: Commission found the applicant's failure to use the internal process was attributable to the applicant
Legal_Rule: Under s. 41(1)(a), the Commission may decline a complaint if other grievance procedures have not been exhausted
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination by the employer
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence and availability of the internal harassment complaint process, timeline provided by Chief of Defence Staff
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: The Commission declined the complaint due to unexhausted internal procedures
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of policy and directives, procedural timelines
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission’s decision to dismiss the complaint
Legal_Provision: s. 41(1)(a) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Material Facts in Immigration Context
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Application Dispute
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Extrinsic evidence from employer (Plastik) used without notification
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant, but procedural fairness obligations on decision maker
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's employment history questioned without opportunity to respond
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Visa officers must provide opportunity to respond to extrinsic evidence, consider all relevant work experience, and notify of language assessment changes
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No response opportunity provided to applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, third-party verification, application forms
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of refusal decision and re-determination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to procedural fairness and assessment criteria

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Application Dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and accuracy of information in visa assessment
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned and referred back for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not given chance to explain discrepancies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on truthfulness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of unverified extrinsic evidence without notice
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of notification regarding language requirements and employment verification
Crimes.Application_Error: Overlooking relevant work experience and applying new language rules without notice
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Compliance with procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to inform and provide fair opportunity to respond
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience and language proficiency scoring
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies in employment verification, no finding of intentional fraud

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration Application Dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and allegations of misrepresentation
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned and referred to different visa officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not informed of concerns or allowed to address discrepancies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employer verification, job description documents, language test requirements
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections on misrepresentation and procedural rights
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unfair reliance on unverified evidence and failure to disclose regulatory changes
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to notify applicant of new language requirements and disregard of relevant experience
Crimes.Application_Error: Incorrect application of scoring criteria and assessment rules
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and accurate application of immigration rules
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Researcher/tutor role deemed relevant but excluded
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to ensure fairness in assessment process
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience evaluation and language proficiency
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct finding of fraud; issues centered on process and communication

Dispute_Type: Classification of farming activities for tax deduction purposes
Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff was a 'class (I) farmer' entitled to deduct farming losses under s. 31 of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Law: Section 31 of the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's time spent on farming, capital investment, borrowing, reduction in reliance on managerial job, impact of drought and economic conditions
Decision_Outcome: Judgment in favor of the plaintiff
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff demonstrated commitment to farming as chief source of income
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff moved to farm, invested savings, worked long hours, borrowed heavily
Legal_Rule: A taxpayer is a 'class (I) farmer' if farming is their chief source of income or combined with another source, considering time, capital, and profitability
Standard_of_Review: Assessment of facts and application of statutory criteria
Grounds_for_Claim: Entitlement to deduct farming losses based on classification as class (I) farmer
Outcome_on_Merits: Plaintiff qualifies as a class (I) farmer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Investment of savings, loans taken, hours worked, shift from managerial work, agricultural challenges
Evidence_Type: Financial records, time allocation, loan documents, employment history
Remedy_Requested: Full deduction of farming losses for 1978–1980
Outcome: Allowed full deduction of farming losses

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutional challenge to vagueness of Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention is unconstitutionally vague under Charter s.7
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 98 of IRPA incorporating Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Deng's evidence was found unreliable and self-serving
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, documentary evidence, claims of persecution
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility and serious reasons to believe in commission of serious non-political crime
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of refugee protection claim
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged fraud in visa application and misrepresentation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious reasons for considering that a serious non-political crime was committed
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; Board considered all relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Fundamental justice under s.7 of the Charter
Crimes.Application_Factor: Overstayed visa and claimed refugee status after entry

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with conditions of temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA (failure to leave by departure date)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Entered on visitor visa, remained beyond authorized period
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Former temporary resident, subsequently refugee claimant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fraud related to entry and stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Translation issues, adjournment requests, bias allegations
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Admissibility and eligibility for refugee protection
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa records, testimony, criminal allegations from home country
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of lawful stay or justification for overstay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubt cast on applicant’s overall credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible due to serious criminality and non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to consider commission of serious non-political crime
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant inadmissible under s.98 IRPA due to alleged fraud and lack of credibility
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant has committed a serious non-political crime
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, s.98 IRPA
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Refugee status determination with admissibility assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board found evidence of fraud in China credible enough to support exclusion
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On Minister to show serious reasons for considering commission of crime
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s testimony deemed inconsistent and self-serving
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes individuals with serious reasons for considering they committed serious non-political crimes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution based on alleged criminal charges in home country
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to Article 1F(b) bar
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegations of financial fraud in China, lack of corroborating evidence from applicant
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, IRPA, Charter of Rights
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denied wrongdoing, claimed political motivation in home country charges
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, witness statements, applicant testimony

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged fraud in home country leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether fraud constitutes serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, Section 98 IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims were not credible; evidence viewed as self-serving
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, immigration documents, foreign legal documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to alleged fraud charges in China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Seriousness of alleged fraud and lack of credible rebuttal
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation in immigration forms and omission of criminal allegations
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious reasons for considering commission of serious non-political crime
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No material evidence ignored; procedural fairness upheld
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard under s.98 IRPA aligned with fundamental justice
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in visa and refugee application

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility assessment and consideration of country conditions
Credibility_Assessment: Minor inconsistencies deemed trivial; lack of proper analysis on credibility
Evidence_Type: Threats from Taliban, letter from aid agency
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by the Taliban in Afghanistan
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, corroboration, delay in application, and country conditions
Application_Error: Failure to provide transparent and justified reasoning for dismissing evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Letter from aid agency without sufficient explanation
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision overturned by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on alleged complicity in international crimes
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F of the Refugee Convention, Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Outcome: RPD concluded Mr. Blanco was complicit in crimes against humanity due to service in Colombian navy
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity through association with state actor (Colombian navy) involved in human rights abuses
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; RPD decision set aside and remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Refugee Protection Division (RPD) exclusion decision under review
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Mr. Blanco claimed refugee protection in Canada
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Colombian state institutions, particularly military branches, assessed for involvement in abuses
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Service in national armed forces allegedly linked to systematic human rights violations
Crimes.Credibility: RPD finding deemed patently unreasonable due to insufficient evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention, Section 98(1)(f) of IRPA
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Questioned due to alleged systemic abuses by state actors
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systematic and widespread human rights violations
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Colombian Navy (alleged, but not sufficiently established)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on alleged complicity in war crimes
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F of the Refugee Convention, Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Outcome: RPD concluded Mr. Blanco was complicit in war crimes due to service in Colombian navy
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity via membership in armed force implicated in international crimes
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside and remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Judicial review of RPD exclusion decision
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee claimant status sought by Mr. Blanco
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Assessment of conduct of Colombian navy and naval intelligence
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Length of service and rank in armed forces linked to potential knowledge of abuses
Crimes.Credibility: Finding of complicity found patently unreasonable due to lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention, Section 98(1)(f) of IRPA
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Concerns about adequacy due to alleged systemic violations by military
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Alleged widespread and systematic human rights abuses during internal conflict
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Colombian Navy and Naval Intelligence (alleged but not proven systematically involved)

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on alleged complicity in crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F of the Refugee Convention, Section 98 of IRPA
Crimes.Outcome: RPD concluded Mr. Blanco was complicit due to rank, length of service, and alleged knowledge
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Membership and service in state military entity allegedly responsible for atrocities
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found decision patently unreasonable; remitted for reassessment
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Judicial review of administrative decision denying refugee protection
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Refugee protection applicant under exclusion clause scrutiny
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Evaluation of whether Colombian navy engaged in systematic abuses
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Duration and position within military structure suggesting possible awareness
Crimes.Credibility: RPD's conclusion lacked evidentiary foundation; deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a) of the Refugee Convention, Section 98(1)(f) of IRPA
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Questioned in context of broader military human rights record
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systematic attacks against civilian population as part of internal conflict
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Colombian Navy (insufficient evidence of systematic criminal conduct)

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to find the applicant not credible patently unreasonable?
Outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed, upholding the Board's decision.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board questioned Mr. Borate's credibility due to inconsistencies in his claims and lack of supporting evidence.
Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence linking Feroz Khan to Mr. Borate
No corroborating evidence for claims (e.g., newspaper article)
Basis_of_Claim: Refugee status based on alleged persecution due to association with Feroz Khan
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony and absence of corroborating documentation
Decision_Outcome: Dismissal of the application for judicial review
Document_Fraud: Missing or incomplete documents such as updated address proof

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Ali was an active MQM member for 7 years, held leadership roles, and fundraised
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Denial of knowledge of MQM’s violent activities despite credible evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over refugee claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ali's denial of knowledge assessed as not credible
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Complicity requiring knowledge and participation in shared common purpose
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Active membership, leadership role, fundraising, and knowledge of MQM's crimes
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Complicity in murder as part of crimes against humanity
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Organized armed group (MQM), with complicit members
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Systematic violence, use of political extremism to justify acts
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: None established due to active involvement
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Association with a group engaged in ongoing violent activities
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of reoffending or continued support for violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Threat posed by association with terrorist or violent extremist organization
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, based on political opposition or extortion
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, organizational records, public reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ali's claims of ignorance not credible given leadership role

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection due to complicity in torture

Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights law, Refugee Convention
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Immigration and Refugee Board decision upheld
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.Protected_Group: Not applicable – individual accused, not seeking protection as member of protected group
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Victims of MQM violence including political dissidents
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: MQM operated with impunity; state protection inadequate in context
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in and support of organization committing torture
Crimes.Credibility: Mr. Ali's denial of knowledge deemed not credible
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Inadequate in Pakistan regarding MQM activities at relevant time

Legal_Issue: Whether the IRB's denial of an adjournment for the applicant's refugee status hearing was reasonable under Rule 48(4)
Governing_Law: Rule 48(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Outcome: IRB's decision was unreasonable; set aside and referred back for redetermination
Legal_Rule: Rule 48(4) outlines factors for adjournment decisions, including exceptional circumstances, preparation time, counsel availability, and potential injustice
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of adjournment despite timely request and potential injustice
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for new hearing
Key_Evidence_Considered: Three weeks' notice, immediate retention of counsel, rejection of proposed dates, lack of peremptory dates
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Rule 48(4)
Defendant_Response: IRB denied adjournment, focusing on late retention of counsel
Outcome: Court granted judicial review, set aside IRB decision, ordered new panel to reassess claim

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependents in immigration application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Natt failed to disclose her children in her second visa application; adoption was void, so children were not examined during her permanent residence application.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident seeking to sponsor children
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to omission of dependents
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of dependent children in application
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over IAD decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa application records, adoption documentation, IAD findings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure and supporting evidence for dependents at time of application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility questioned due to non-disclosure and invalid adoption
Crimes.Outcome: Children ineligible for sponsorship under family class
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 117(9)(d) excludes family members not examined during sponsor’s permanent residence process

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration sponsorship ineligible due to non-examination under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Sponsorship eligibility under family class
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility of children for sponsorship under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative assessment due to failure to disclose and void adoption
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Application forms, adoption documents, immigration records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Children not examined during sponsor’s residency application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Non-examination of dependents at time of permanent residence grant
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before IAD, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to list children in visa application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Compliance with regulatory requirements for family class inclusion
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Statutory interpretation of 'family class' under IRPR
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dependents must be examined during sponsor’s application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Void adoption document submitted or relied upon

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Eligibility for sponsorship under family class
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether children qualify under s. 117(9)(d) despite non-disclosure
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to omission and reliance on void adoption
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration applications, court declaration of void adoption
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Attempted sponsorship after non-disclosure and invalid adoption
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Children were not examined when sponsor obtained permanent residence
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of dependent children from original application
Crimes.Application_Factor: Examination requirement for family class membership
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission or reliance on void adoption documents

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa officer's assessment of job qualifications and intent to leave Canada
Outcome: Decisions quashed, applications remanded for reconsideration
Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted applicants' qualifications and return intentions
Basis_of_Claim: Perceived lack of job qualifications and intent to return home
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of justification and transparency in officer's decision
Application_Error: Insufficient rationale for doubting qualifications and return intent
Application_Factor: Job qualifications, intent to leave Canada
Decision_Outcome: Work permits denied initially, later set aside by court

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility assessment in refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Found implausible due to inconsistencies in testimony
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility issues, lack of corroborative evidence
Application_Factor: Use of gender guidelines without requiring corroboration

Legal_Issue: Scope of discovery under Rule 3 of the Federal Court Rules
Governing_Law: Rule 3 of the Federal Court Rules
Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of relevance of nearly 800 discovery questions
Decision_Outcome: Apotex's discovery motion partially granted, largely dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Apotex bore burden to justify broad discovery scope
Legal_Rule: Rule 3 allows courts discretion to manage cases efficiently; discovery must be relevant and proportionate
Grounds_for_Claim: Apotex challenged validity of Merck's Lisinopril patent (Patent 350) on multiple grounds
Outcome_on_Merits: Discovery limited to matters relevant to Patent 350; broader inquiries dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Categories of discovery questions related to patent validity
Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules, Canadian patent law
Defendant_Response: Merck argued most discovery requests were irrelevant
Remedy_Requested: Apotex sought broad discovery; Merck sought to limit scope
Outcome: Costs awarded to Merck; restricted discovery allowed
